items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Also called "multi-story cropping" or "agroforestry", it allows farmers to seamlessly integrate their farm into the surrounding landscape and diversify their product offerings.

Originating in tropical Brazil, forest farming is well-suited for land on the margins of forests. It involves thinning a forest to allow for crops to grow in the understory, including native ornamentals, fungi, fruit, timber, and forest food crops. Other agroforestry methods mentioned include silvopasture (combining forestry and ranching) and alley cropping (planting specialty crops between tree rows).

Key benefits of forest farming include:
- Improved water and soil quality, with trees holding more water and carbon
- Habitat for beneficial insects, birds, mammals, fungi, and microbes
- Ability to grow specialized crops like mushrooms, ramps, syrups, and edible roots

Farmers are advised to inventory their existing natural resources, consult extension services to develop a management plan, and explore diverse marketing channels for forest products. Regulations around wild-harvested plants also need to be considered.

Overall, the article states that forest farming can be an inexpensive and ecologically-beneficial way for farmers with forested land to diversify their operations, even on a small scale.

items.title: Jan 16 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: The second week of the year brought a fleeting taste of spring, with average temperatures between the mid-30s to upper 40s; 8 to 12 degrees above normal. Some of the more impressive daytime high temperatures this week included 69 in Kaskaskia and 68 in Carbondale. January to date has been 7 to 12 degrees above normal statewide, and has been a top 10 warmest first half of January on record in most parts of the state.…
items.summary:
The second week of January 2026 saw above-normal temperatures, ranging from the mid-30s to upper 40s, which were 8-12 degrees above average. Some areas reported high temperatures as warm as 69¬∞F in Kaskaskia and 68¬∞F in Carbondale. However, precipitation was scarce, with only 0.1 to 0.75 inches of rainfall across the state. January to date has been 7-12 degrees warmer and 0.5-1 inch drier than normal statewide, with southern Illinois experiencing a top 5 driest winter on record so far. 

The article notes that the mild weather will come to an abrupt end this weekend, with highs struggling to reach 20¬∞F in northern Illinois and above freezing in southern Illinois. Little precipitation is expected, with less than 0.25 inches of light snow forecast over the next 7 days. The colder weather is expected to persist through the first week of February, but chances for better precipitation increase in the final week of January.

The article also covers the latest WILLAg.org radio programming, including the Commodity Week panel discussion featuring experts from Roach Ag, AgMarket.net, and Global Commodity Analytics and Consulting, as well as the daily Closing Market Report.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- Spray drones are being increasingly evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application.
- Key benefits include timely applications, reduced field traffic, and improved access to difficult areas.
- Adoption requires careful consideration of regulations, training, insurance, and management practices.

Regulations:
- FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Certificate is required to operate drones commercially.
- FAA Part 137 Certification is required for aerial application of pesticides.
- Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS) licensing is required for all aerial applicators.
- Only products labeled for aerial application may be legally applied using a drone.

Insurance:
- Most standard farm liability policies do not cover aerial pesticide application or aircraft-related risks.
- Farmers need chemical liability, general liability, and hull/physical damage coverage.

Equipment Selection:
- Consider spray tank capacity, battery life, nozzle options, GPS guidance, and local dealer support.

Training and Safe Operation:
- Proper training is essential for effective and safe spray drone use.
- Calibration, weather monitoring, and routine maintenance are critical.
- Verifying swath width is crucial for consistent spray performance.

Gradual Adoption:
- Start on a limited scale with small acreage or trial fields.
- Develop efficient procedures for mixing, refilling, and battery exchange.
- Cautiously evaluate dry product uses like cover crop seeding or spot fertilizer placement.

Resources:
- Iowa State University Extension, Digital Agriculture Innovation Lab, licensed equipment dealers, and IDALS.

Key Dates:
- February 24-25, 2026: 2-day FAA Part 107 training workshop in Ames, IA.

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Winter sowing involves starting seeds in containers like milk jugs or plastic bags and placing them outdoors, where the cold, moist conditions help the seeds break dormancy. This results in hardier transplants and plants that mature sooner.

The article then provides details on the best flowers and vegetables to winter sow:

Vegetables:
- Cabbages - Excellent cold-tolerant options include standard cabbages, Napa cabbages, and 'Carex' cabbages with shorter maturation.
- Spinach - Varieties like 'Avon' and 'Space' are good options, as they are resistant to mildew and bolting.
- Onions - Long-day, short-day, and intermediate-day onion varieties can all be winter sown. Bunching onions and shallots also work well.
- Leafy greens - Kale, collards, chard, watercress, microgreens, bok choy, arugula, and beet/turnip greens are all excellent for winter sowing.

Flowers:
- Pansies - Hardy pansies can be planted now for spring blooms.
- Echinacea - Needs cold stratification, which is provided by the winter sowing method.
- Snapdragons - There are four groups, each suited for different light and temperature conditions.
- Larkspur - Also known as delphinium, these produce beautiful true-blue flowers and attract pollinators.
- Scabiosa - Also called pincushion flowers, these attract beneficial insects to the farm.

The article emphasizes that winter sowing provides the benefits of direct sowing with less risk, and highlights the importance of choosing the right plants for this method.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6-29. These meetings, organized by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach, will provide farmers and crop production professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season.

The meetings will cover a variety of topics, including:
- Crop market and climate outlooks for 2026
- Nitrates and drinking water
- Profitable nutrient management
- Southern rust
- Transition planning
- Robots and drones

Early-bird registration is $75 until the week before each meeting, after which it will be $100. Private pesticide applicator recertification will also be available at each location for a separate fee of $30.

The goal of the Crop Advantage Series is to help producers manage potential issues by sharing the most up-to-date scientific knowledge from Iowa State University researchers. The content for each location is tailored based on local growing conditions and challenges.

For more information, farmers can contact crops@iastate.edu or their regional ISU Extension and Outreach field agronomist. Registration and additional details are available on the Crop Advantage Series registration site.

items.title: Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists
items.description: Outstanding producers from California, Kansas, Ohio, Oregon and Wisconsin will be recognized for excellence, leadership and innovation. Kansas City, Mo., (Dec. 15, 2025) ‚Äì Farm Journal has announced three finalists for the prestigious 2026 Top Producer of the Year Award, honoring some of the most progressive and successful farm operations in the country. The winner and finalists will be […] The post Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists appeared first
items.summary:
The Farm Journal has announced the finalists for the prestigious 2026 Top Producer of the Year Award, recognizing outstanding producers from California, Kansas, Ohio, Oregon, and Wisconsin for their excellence, leadership, and innovation.

The three finalists are:

1. Alsum Farms, Friesland, Wis. - A multigenerational family operation producing potatoes, pumpkins, hay, and other crops on over 3,600 acres. The business is fully vertically integrated.

2. Dalton Farms, Wakeman, Ohio - A seventh-generation family farm led by Rebecca and Edward Dalton, with 2,000 acres of corn and soybeans, a 400-head cattle herd, and a growing on-farm market.

3. Splitter Farms, Sterling, Kan. - Led by Matt and Janna Splitter, this Kansas row-crop operation spans 1,400 owned acres with nearly 18,500 acres farmed annually through cash rent and custom work.

The winner and finalists will be recognized at the 2026 Top Producer Summit in Nashville, Tenn., on February 9-11. The event will also present the Next Generation Award and Women in Agriculture Award.

The 2026 Next Generation Award winner is Tim Nuss, El Dorado Hills/Lodi, Calif., who farms various crops and is also involved in ag tech and influencing. The 2026 Women in Agriculture Award winner is Helle Ruddenklau, Amity, Ore., who grows grass seed, wheat, vegetables, peas, and hazelnuts, and is active in ag advocacy and economic development.

The Top Producer Awards are sponsored by BASF, Fendt, and Pro Farmer.

items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5.

The event will feature research on sorghum's value as a forage crop compared to corn. Sorghum is more drought-tolerant, has lower nitrogen requirements, and is not susceptible to the tar spot pathogen. Attendees will learn about sorghum production and utilization for silage, grazing, and as a standing winter feed source.

Speakers will include Purdue experts such as Keith Johnson, Mitch Tuinstra, Brad Shelton, Jason Tower, Nick Minton, and Jeff Jackson. They will discuss topics like plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality.

The event will include venue tours from 3-5 pm and 6-8 pm, as well as a dinner and bull test station tour from 5-6 pm.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
Farmer sentiment improved in July 2024 despite concerns over financial performance:

- The Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113 in July.
- The Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119.
- This positive shift was attributed to fewer respondents reporting worsened conditions compared to a year ago and a decrease in those expecting negative future outcomes.
- High input costs remained the biggest concern for 34% of farmers, while 29% cited the risk of lower crop and livestock prices, up from 25% in June.
- The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points in July to 81, 6 points lower than July 2023, reflecting farmers' worries about weakening commodity prices and high input costs.
- The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points in July to 38, though it remains 7 points lower than July 2023, as fewer producers believe it's a bad time to make large investments.
- The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index rose to 118 from 115 in June, while the Long-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index dropped 6 points to 146.
- Nearly three-fourths (72%) of crop farmer respondents expect cash rental rates to remain the same in 2025 compared to 2024.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
Purdue researchers are taking an interdisciplinary approach to assess the emerging tar spot disease in corn:

- Tar spot, a fungal disease, was first detected in the U.S. in 2015 and has since spread to 16 states and Ontario, Canada by 2022. It has also affected crops in 15 other countries.

- The research team, led by C.D. Cruz, associate professor of botany and plant pathology at Purdue, is using a mix of statistical, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, artificial intelligence, and computer vision methods to understand the dynamics of tar spot.

- The research is funded by two USDA grants totaling nearly $1.1 million. Collaborators include researchers from Colombia, Mexico, Ecuador, South Korea, and the U.S.

- Researchers have developed a digital method (SCDA) to quantify tar spot in corn, which they have tested against human raters with promising results. They are now refining the training methods to improve the model's accuracy.

- The team is also exploring the use of drone imagery, weather data, and AI-based data fusion to capture details about the tar spot pathosystem, going beyond traditional weather-based models.

- The interdisciplinary approach involves challenges, but it can lead to better problem-solving by leveraging the expertise of researchers from different fields.

- The overall goal is to quantify and model tar spot severity by integrating various data sources, with the aim of providing rapid and accurate information to stakeholders.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair
items.description: In addition to 4-H and open sheep shows, the Indiana Sheep Association (ISA) is sponsoring sheep-themed competitions, vendors and educational opportunities at this year‚Äôs Indiana State Fair, with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN SW).
items.summary:
Key Summary:

The Indiana Sheep Association (ISA), with support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN S&W), is sponsoring various sheep-themed events and competitions at the 2024 Indiana State Fair, including:

- The Wool and Ewe Room and Ewe2 boutique selling wool products and Indiana lamb throughout the fair
- Open wool judging and wool sale on August 2 at 10 a.m.
- Make It With Wool (MIWW) competition and fashion show on August 4 at 2 p.m.
- Indiana State Fair Shearing Contest on August 4 at 5 p.m.
- Taste from Indiana Farms lamb sampling event from August 8-11 from 11 a.m.-6 p.m.
- Sheep to Shawl competition on August 18 at 10 a.m.

Additionally, sheep will be featured in the Blue Ribbon Pavilion for open and 4-H shows from August 4-20. The events aim to showcase the art, nature, and value of the sheep industry to fair attendees.

The ISA was originally founded in 1876 as the Indiana Wool Growers Association. The IN S&W program collects 0.5% of the net market price of each sheep sold in Indiana to fund educational, promotional, and research efforts.

items.title: Purdue Extension to present engaging art and nature demonstrations at Indiana State Fair
items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields. Fairgoers will have the opportunity to speak with Purdue University representatives about agricultural and nature-related topics, which are available year-round through Purdue Extension.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Purdue Extension will present interactive demonstrations and exhibits at the 2024 Indiana State Fair, which runs from August 2-18.
- The fair's theme is "The Art & Nature of Fun" in collaboration with Newfields.
- Purdue Extension exhibits will be located throughout the fairgrounds, covering topics like entomology, human health, forestry, and animal sciences.
- Specific activities include a Block Party, Book Party, Captain Cash financial management exhibit, and displays on pollinators and master gardening.
- The Food Science Department will host "What's Growing on My Spinach?" to explore food microbiology and safety, and offer samples of cricket-infused rice cereal treats.
- Seed art displays related to the fair's theme will be featured in livestock barns and the Purdue Extension Building.
- The Pioneer Village in the fairgrounds will transport visitors to the 1800s and feature antique tractors, a farm toy show, and more.

items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!
items.description: Check out the new NPM publication! This two-page publication gives a visual overview of the potassium cycle as it relates to general Wisconsin cropping systems, and on the second page, outlines some key potassium concepts …
items.summary: The University of Wisconsin-Madison has released a new publication called "Potassium Cycle" that provides a visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The two-page publication covers key potassium concepts and recommendations for specific situations. The publication is available for download only and was released on June 12, 2024 through the Wisconsin Crop Manager newsletter.

items.title: Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update
items.description: Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, University of Wisconsin-Madison Winter wheat in Wisconsin continues to move through growth stages at record pace. We are about 10-14 days …
items.summary:
Stripe rust disease is likely to be seen this season, though it has not been detected yet. Farmers are advised to scout fields and report any confirmed cases to the Plant Disease Diagnostic Clinic.  

Fusarium head blight (FHB) is also a concern, as the moderate temperatures and adequate precipitation this season create conditions favorable for the disease. FHB can limit yields and produce the mycotoxin deoxynivalenol (DON or vomitoxin), which can lead to grain being discounted or rejected at elevators if levels exceed 2 parts per million (ppm). Farmers will need to manage this disease.

The article was written on May 20, 2024 by Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, and Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

items.title: Questions to consider prior to replanting a soybean field
items.description: Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist, UW-Madison Early in the growing season, abiotic (freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, etc.) and biotic (slugs, deer, disease, insects, etc.) factors often reduce soybean plant stands. A soybean …
items.summary:
Even minor stand loss warrants assessing the amount and pattern of plant loss. Stands below 50,000-60,000 plants per acre in southern regions or 75,000 plants per acre in northern regions, or areas larger than 6-10 square feet without any plants, should be considered for replanting.

Factors to evaluate include the existing plant stand, distribution, and ability to recover; calendar date and impact on relative maturity; weed management; seed and variety availability; cost to replant and insurance availability; and the tradeoff between a suboptimal stand vs. yield penalty from delayed replanting.

The article references a fact sheet with more detailed guidance, and a separate related article on "Soybean Replant Decisions Made Easy(ish)!".

items.title: Spraying 2,4-D on Soybean in 2024?
items.description: Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager, UW-Madison Division of Extension, Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist, UW-Madison Are you planning to spray 2,4-D for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybean? The 2,4-D …
items.summary:
The only labeled formulation for this application is the 2,4-D choline formulation present in Enlist One and Enlist Duo herbicides. The ester and amine formulations of 2,4-D cannot be used post-emergence in Enlist E3 soybeans. 

When using a 2,4-D ester or amine formulation product for burndown applications, there is a soybean plant back interval of at least 7 days when applying 0.5 lbs ae/acre. If planting Enlist E3 soybeans, Enlist One or Enlist Duo can be applied without this plant back restriction.

The article is a reminder that the product label must be followed, as there have been reports of producers, agronomists, and crop advisors considering using unapproved 2,4-D formulations for post-emergence applications in Enlist E3 soybeans.

The article was written by Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager at UW-Madison Division of Extension, and Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist at UW-Madison. It was posted on May 11, 2024.

items.title: Wisconsin CCA Board Election Results
items.description: Thank you to everyone who provided nominations and voted in the recent Wisconsin CCA Board election. On-behalf of the election process I would like to welcome Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura to the …
items.summary:
The Wisconsin CCA (Certified Crop Adviser) Board election results have been announced. Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura have been elected to the WI CCA Board and are eligible to serve two, three-year terms.

The election process was managed by the Outreach Program Manager, Daniel H. Smith, from the Crops and Soils Program at the University of Wisconsin-Madison Division of Extension.

All WI CCAs in good standing are eligible for nomination and can vote in future elections, which will be held in early 2025. Individuals who did not get elected this time are encouraged to apply again in the next election cycle.

The announcement was made on May 10, 2024 in the WCM (Wisconsin Crop Manager) newsletter and the "What's New?" section.
